bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Captain John Hyde and Company, July 26, 1731

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to London merchants Captain John Hyde and Company, July 26, 1731, to enquire why he has not received reports of sales of tobacco sent over the past several years and of bills of exchange. He also encloses an invoice (not present) for goods for his children.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Captain John Hyde and Company, July 26, 1731

opener.dateline:
Rappahannock, [Lancaster County, Virginia]
July 26. 1731.
Capt John Hyde & Comany

div1.p:
All the letters I have receiv'd from you this year
are contain'd in three lines at the bottom of my Invoice sent in the
Rebeccah Capt Malbon.

I cannot but be a little concern'd no futher intelligence
is given to me of the business I have in yr hands Accots are yet to be
render'd me for the following tobos vizt forty hogsheads of my own
crops in the Providence pr. Woodward in 1729 ten hogsheads pr. [the] Bailey
the same year belonging to Mr. Burwells Estate twenty hogsheads
stemm'd tobo my own Crop Per the Providence in 1730. and 7 hogsheads do in
the Bailey stemm'd alsoe none of these tobaccos are made any mention of
although the Ships tha[t] Carried them have visited us again & Again
Last year I sent Bills of Exchange upon Yr.selfs for £29.18.10 drawn
by Churchil Jones and for £10" by Dennis McCarty I presume by yr.
Silence these bills I am credited with perhaps your letters may have
Miscarry'd which hath occasion'd this disapointment to me

Herein I send you an Invoice for some things for two of
my children desiring the directions therein may be observ'd I am-

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Letter book, 1731 July 9-1732 July 13 , Robert Carter Papers (acc. no. 3807), Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.

[1] The Rebecca was probably a London ship; she was of 300 tons, had a crew of 11, and was commanded by Samuel Malbon in 1731. (Adm. 65/195, found in the microfilms of the Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.)

[2] Thomas Woodward commanded the Providence, a ship owned by Captain John Hyde & Company, during a number of voyages to the colony, 1723-1729. (Survey Report 6800 summarizing Adm. 68/194 and Survey Report 6801 summarizing Adm 68/195, Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia, and Carter's letter to the firm, 1723 September 17.)

[3] The Bailey was a London ship owned by William Dawkins and commanded at various times by Adam Graves (1725-1730) and by Thomas Dove (1731-1732). She was a vessel of some 250 tons and carried 15-17 crew members. (Survey report 6801 summarizing Adm. 68/195, 156v, and other data in Adm. 68/194 and /196, found in the microfilms of the Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia; A letter of Carter's executors to Dawkins 1738 May 10 refers to "your ship Bailey.")
